text: Every aspect of our lives has been affected by DT NN . DT JJ economy has slowed , NNS have retreated to their homes and thousands have died or become seriously ill . At this frightening stage of DT crisis , PRP ’s difficult to focus on anything else . But as DT International Agency has VBN , DT effects of NN are likely to be temporary but DT other JJ emergency – NN NN – is not . Stopping DT spread of NN is paramount , but NN action must RB continue . And PRP can draw JJ lessons and opportunities from DT current NN crisis when tackling planetary NN . S&P NNP Ratings this week VBD measures to contain NNP - CD have pushed DT JJ economy into recession . JJ analyst Lauri Myllyvirta estimates DT pandemic MD have reduced JJ NNS by 200 megatonnes of carbon dioxide to date , as air travel grinds to a halt , factories close down and NN demand falls . In DT first four weeks of DT pandemic , coal consumption in NNP alone fell by 36 % , and oil refining capacity reduced by 34 % . In JJ ways , what PRP ’re seeing now is a rapid and unplanned version of JJ “ degrowth ” – DT transition some academics and activists have for decades VBN is necessary to address NN NN , and leave a habitable NN for future generations . Read more : Life in a ' degrowth ' economy , and why PRP might actually enjoy PRP Degrowth is a proposed slowing of growth in sectors WDT damage DT environment , such as fossil fuel industries , until DT economy operates within NNP ’s limits . PRP is a voluntary , planned and equitable transition in developed nations which necessarily involves an increased focus on DT environment , human well - being , and capabilities ( good NN , decent work , education , and a safe and healthy environment ) . Such a transformation MD be profound , and so far no nation has shown DT will to implement PRP . PRP MD require JJ economies to “ decouple ” from carbon to prevent NN - related crises . But DT current unintended JJ slowdown opens DT door to such a transition , which MD bring myriad benefits to DT NN . DT idea of sustainable degrowth is very different to a recession . PRP involves scaling back environmentally damaging sectors of DT economy , and strengthening others . NN NN has been declared a JJ emergency , yet to date DT NN has largely failed to address PRP . In contrast , DT JJ policy response to DT NN emergency has been fast and furious . EX are several reasons for this dramatic difference . NN NN is a relatively slow - moving crisis , whereas NN visibly escalates over days , even hours , increasing our perception of DT risks involved . CD thing WDT history teaches PRP about politics and DT human condition in times of peril , PRP often take a “ crisis management ” approach to dealing with serious threats . Read more : How changes brought on by NN MD help tackle NN NN As others have observed , DT slow increase in JJ temperatures means humans can psychologically adjust as DT situation worsens , making DT problem seem less urgent and meaning NNS are less willing to accept drastic policy measures . DT JJ response to DT NN crisis shows IN governments can take immediate , radical emergency measures , which VBP beyond purely JJ concerns , to protect DT well - being of all . Specifically , EX are practical lessons and opportunities PRP can take away from DT NN emergency as PRP seek to tackle NN NN : Act early : DT NN pandemic shows DT crucial importance of early action to prevent catastrophic consequences . Governments in Taiwan , South Korea and Singapore acted quickly to implement quarantine and screening measures , and have seen relatively small numbers of infections . Italy , on DT other hand , whose NN waited too long to act , is now DT epicentre of DT NN . Read more : Running out of things to do in isolation ? VB back in DT garden with these ideas from 4 experts VB slow , VB local : NN has forced an immediate scale - down of how PRP travel and live . NNS are forging local connections , shopping locally , working from home and limiting consumption to what PRP need . Researchers have identified IN fears about personal well - being represent a major barrier to political support for DT degrowth movement to date . However with social distancing expected to be in place for months , our scaled - down lives MD become DT “ JJ normal ” . JJ NNS MD realise IN consumption and personal well - being are not inextricably linked . JJ JJ thinking is needed . A transition to sustainable degrowth can help . PRP need to shift JJ attention from GDP as an indicator of well - being , towards other measures WDT put NNS and DT environment first , such as NNP Zealand ’s well - being budget , Bhutan ’s gross national happiness index , or Ecuador ’s social philosophy of buen vivir ( good living ) . Spend on clean NN : DT International NNP Agency ( IEA ) says clean NN should be “ at DT heart of stimulus plans to counter DT NN crisis ” . DT IEA has called on governments to launch sustainable stimulus packages focused on clean NN technologies . PRP says hydrogen and carbon - capture RB need major investment to bring them to scale , which MD be helped by DT current low interest rates . Governments MD RB use NN stimulus packages to reskill workers to service DT JJ “ green ” economy , and address challenges in healthcare , sanitation , aged care , food security and education . As NN scientist Katharine Hayhoe VBD this month : DT NN crisis is devastating , but failing to tackle NN NN because of DT pandemic only compounds DT tragedy . Instead , PRP must draw on DT lessons of NN to address DT NN challenge .

text: In 1916 , Antarctic explorer Ernest Shackleton was forced to make a treacherous voyage across DT open waters of DT Southern Ocean after his ship Endurance was crushed by pack NN and sank in DT Weddell NNP . Along with five members of his party , Shackleton set out for DT island of South Georgia in a 23 - foot - long wooden lifeboat named DT James Caird . Eleven days into DT trip , on NNP 5 , Shackleton thought he spied a clearing in DT murky sky above . What he was actually seeing was n’t a break in DT clouds , but DT white crest of a monstrous wave bearing down on them . “ During twenty - six NNS ’ experience of DT ocean in all its moods I had not encountered a wave so gigantic , ” Shackleton MD later write in his book South : DT Story of Shackleton ’s Last Expedition 1914 - 1917 . “ PRP was a mighty upheaval of DT ocean , a thing quite apart from DT big white - capped seas WDT had been our tireless enemies for JJ days . ” Shackleton ’s account remains CD of DT most evocative descriptions of DT westerly winds WDT circle DT globe between 30 and 60 degrees latitude in both hemispheres and DT colossal waves PRP whip up in DT Southern Ocean . Today , DT southern westerlies are back in focus for entirely different reasons : their potential impact on NN NN . DT NN ’s oceans take up more than a quarter of DT carbon humans are emitting into DT atmosphere , partially mitigating DT greenhouse effect of DT carbon . And DT Southern Ocean accounts for nearly 40 percent of this marine carbon absorption , even though PRP makes up only CD - fifth of NNP ’s ocean surface area . EX MD be enormous consequences for our already VBG NN from even a small reduction in DT Southern Ocean ’s ability to suck up carbon from DT atmosphere . NNS say this reduction MD already be happening , and PRP suspect IN DT westerlies in DT Southern Hemisphere , which are stronger than their northern counterparts because PRP blow mostly over open NN , are to blame . Records of actual wind speeds , as well as estimates of wind speeds from measurements of atmospheric pressure , provide clear signs IN DT westerlies in both hemispheres are shifting toward DT poles and intensifying . NN models show IN these changes are partly due to JJ NN , and research is afoot to determine if PRP are hindering DT Southern Ocean ’s capacity to pull carbon out of DT atmosphere . “ EX are questions about what ’s VBG to happen if DT winds continue to VB stronger , ” says paleoclimate scientist Krystyna Saunders of DT Australian Nuclear NNP and Technology Organisation in Sydney . “ How much can DT oceans actually absorb ? ” Saunders and her colleagues are finding clues IN over DT past 12,000 NNS of NNP ’s history , higher wind speeds and greater concentrations of carbon dioxide in DT atmosphere have gone together . If this link between wind and CO ₂ holds true today , PRP will lead to higher levels of DT greenhouse gas in DT atmosphere , which will speed up NN NN , which MD further intensify DT westerlies . EX ’s growing evidence IN , at least in DT winter months when DT westerlies are at their most violent , some parts of DT Southern Ocean are giving off more of DT gas than was previously estimated . PRP has all DT makings of a vicious cycle . DT westerlies are DT result of a JJ atmospheric circulation system , starting with what is called DT Hadley cell . DT cell forms as warm , moist air near DT equator rises into DT upper atmosphere and then , as PRP cools and dries , much of PRP sinks down toward NNP at about 30 degrees latitude in each hemisphere . Lower in DT atmosphere , this air moves back toward DT equator , completing DT cell . Some of this downward - moving mass of air escapes DT Hadley cell and moves away from DT equator , and is deflected by NNP ’s rotation , creating DT westerlies . Because DT westerlies form at DT edge of each hemisphere ’s Hadley cell WDT is closest to DT pole , DT bigger DT size of DT cell , DT more DT winds move toward DT pole . Data collected by weather balloons , satellites and other means VBG back to 1960 show IN NNP ’s tropical belt has widened in DT past few decades by a few degrees of latitude , effectively expanding DT size of DT Hadley cells . This is partly due to JJ NN , as predicted by NN models . At DT same NN , DT westerlies have been pushed poleward . With less distance to cover as PRP circle a narrower part of DT globe , DT law of conservation of angular momentum dictates IN DT winds should increase in speed , much IN an NN skater rotates faster when she draws in her arms . And measurements during DT past three decades show IN DT westerlies have , indeed , intensified . As researchers were making sense of these changes to DT westerlies , other NNS began using measurements of CO₂ levels in DT atmosphere to determine whether DT shifting , speedier westerlies are causing a drop in DT amount of CO ₂ being absorbed by DT Southern Ocean . PRP had reason to suppose IN this MD happen . IN any gas , carbon dioxide exerts a pressure WDT depends on DT amount of DT gas relative to other gases in a mixture . If this so - called partial pressure of carbon dioxide ( pCO₂ ) of DT atmosphere is greater than DT pCO ₂ of DT ocean , then DT ocean will absorb carbon from DT atmosphere . Otherwise PRP will release PRP . And as DT westerlies VBP stronger , DT pCO ₂ of DT Southern Ocean MD VB , due to shifts in DT pattern of ocean currents . DT westerlies drive DT Southern Ocean current WDT circles Antarctica . DT predominantly west - to - east current is further acted upon by a force generated by NNP ’s rotation , known as DT Coriolis force , which deflects moving objects to their right in DT Northern Hemisphere and to their left in DT Southern Hemisphere . DT current circling Antarctica is deflected to its left , or northward , pushing DT surface waters away from DT pole . This sets DT stage for NN from deep in DT Southern Ocean to move to DT surface . Up to 80 percent of all DT deep NN WDT returns to DT surface around DT globe makes DT return in DT Southern Ocean . “ PRP ’s unique , ” says NN scientist Joellen Russell of DT University of Arizona in Tucson . “ EX 's nothing IN PRP in DT NN . ” This massive upwelling of DT deeper , carbon - rich waters of DT Southern Ocean increases DT pCO ₂ of DT ocean surface , which decreases its capacity to act as a carbon sink , DT argument goes . But is this what is actually happening ? DT Southern Ocean has been loath to reveal its workings . This is due to DT complicating effects of local wind patterns and DT fact IN researchers are only just beginning to make direct measurements of DT outgassing of CO ₂ during peak winter months RB . So far , DT data paint a somewhat confusing , and concerning , picture . Previous estimates had shown IN between 1981 and 2004 , DT Southern Ocean absorbed about 80 million fewer metric tons of carbon per NN than expected . This was a cause for concern , given IN DT Southern Ocean is “ DT most important marine carbon sink on DT NN , ” says ocean biogeochemist Peter Landschützer of DT Max Planck Institute for Meteorology in Hamburg , Germany . So Landschützer and his colleagues took a closer look at a JJ database of pCO ₂ values , created from observations of surface waters by instruments deployed in DT NN or carried on research and commercial ships . Known as DT Surface Ocean CO₂ Atlas ( SOCAT ) and established in 2007 , PRP contains almost 26 million observations of JJ oceans and coastal seas from 1957 to 2019 . Since data are sparser for DT earlier decades than for recent NNS , Landschützer ’s team filled in DT gaps using other , less direct but more frequently measured parameters such as NN surface temperature and salinity and their well - understood relationship to pCO ₂ of surface waters . PRP estimated IN DT Southern Ocean had indeed taken in less CO₂ than expected from 1982 to 2001 . DT trend reversed in 2002 , with DT ocean acting as a more vigorous carbon sink all DT way up to 2011 . From 2011 to 2016 , however , DT Southern Ocean went back to being less effective in its carbon absorption . DT team tried to find a link between DT changes in DT Southern Ocean ’s ability to absorb CO ₂ and DT poleward - shifted westerlies . “ PRP were quite surprised IN PRP did not , ” Landschützer says . This called for an explanation , and DT answer turned out to be complicated . Further analysis showed IN DT changing westerlies are , indeed , increasing DT upwelling of carbon - rich deep waters near Antarctica . This effect , though , is being offset further north in DT Southern Ocean by an increased carbon uptake in regions where DT westerlies are blowing less vigorously than in DT past . This MD imply IN EX should be no overall NN in DT absorption of carbon . But Landschützer ’s team found IN DT Southern Ocean ’s ability to absorb carbon is increasing or decreasing over timescales of roughly a decade . DT researchers put these flips down to DT local wind patterns in different parts of DT Southern Ocean known as DT Atlantic , Pacific and Indian sectors . Winds RB seem to VB every decade , as evidenced by about 35 NNS of data , and those local alterations line up well with carbon absorption trends , Landschützer says . All of DT above analysis was based on data collected by ships plying DT Southern Ocean mainly during summer . DT data for DT winter season was spotty ; PRP is hard for ships to venture close to Antarctica at DT NN . So Landschützer ’s team used DT richer summer data and DT sparse winter data to extrapolate and account for DT winter months as best PRP MD . But in recent NNS , researchers have started using floats WDT are offering a JJ , broader glimpse of winter goings - on in DT Southern Ocean . And DT data are disconcerting . Oceanographer Alison Gray of DT University of Washington and her colleagues used data collected by 35 of these autonomous floats , deployed by DT Southern Ocean Carbon and NNP Observations and Modeling ( SOCCOM ) project . DT floats , which had continuously monitored DT top 2,000 meters of DT Southern Ocean waters from NNP 1 , 2014 , to NNP 1 , 2017 , have sensors for a range of ocean surface parameters , and these can be used to calculate DT pCO ₂ of DT surface waters . DT analysis by Gray ’s team showed IN DT Southern Ocean around Antarctica is outgassing significantly more CO₂ in DT winter than Lanschützer ’s methodology estimated . To see if PRP MD resolve DT discrepancy , Landschützer and colleagues combined DT data sets and found IN “ DT truth lies somewhere in DT middle , ” he says : DT carbon uptake is not as low as DT direct float measurements suggest , but neither is PRP as high as estimated by DT ship - only data . While more work will help NN NNS understand exactly what ’s happening in DT Southern Ocean , for DT University of Arizona ’s Russell , DT direct winter data from DT SOCCOM floats is already raising alarms . “ In DT deep winter , when DT winds are howling DT strongest and DT deepest layers are being stirred to DT surface , DT ’s when PRP 're tapping those older carbon waters , ” she says . “ And DT 's what 's worrisome . ” DT deep waters are carbon - rich because of DT microscopic marine algae called phytoplankton WDT live in DT surface waters . DT phytoplankton photosynthesize DT CO₂ in DT NN into organic molecules to build their bodies . When PRP die , PRP sink to DT ocean floor , sequestering DT carbon for centuries . Some phytoplankton are consumed by larger organisms called zooplankton , which in turn are eaten by even bigger creatures whose carbon - rich fecal pellets and dead bodies can RB end up on DT ocean floor , burying ever more carbon in DT deep waters . DT evidence from DT SOCCOM floats suggests IN PRP ’s these deep waters WDT are upwelling during DT Antarctic winters . “ PRP 's DT old rotted NN WDT normally takes hundreds of NNS to circulate out of DT deep , ” Russell says . NNS surmise IN intensifying westerlies are bringing more of this carbon - rich deep NN to DT surface — but PRP need more evidence . CD way to confirm IN speedier westerlies have an impact on Southern Ocean outgassing , and thus on DT levels of atmospheric CO₂ , is to look at past NN evidence . Krystyna Saunders and her colleagues decided to look for some of DT evidence on subantarctic Macquarie Island , which lies about 1,500 kilometers from Tasmania , midway between Australia and Antarctica . At latitude degrees 54S , PRP ’s right in DT main band of DT westerlies . Getting to Macquarie Island is no small feat , even on DT Aurora Australis , a 311 - foot - long icebreaker . Despite its size , DT ship can be tossed around by massive swells , DT kind Shackleton wrote about . “ PRP can be lying down in your bunk , rolling from side to side and head to toe as DT ship swirls around , ” Saunders says . “ If PRP VBP seasick IN me , PRP ’s quite horrible . ” On Macquarie Island , Saunders and her colleagues capitalized on a fortuitous natural record WDT provides clues to how strongly DT winds around DT island have blown in DT past . DT record lies at DT bottom of Emerald Lake , a body of freshwater on DT island ’s western edge . PRP ’s exposed to DT westerlies and thus to salty ocean spray blown in by DT winds : DT greater DT wind speeds , DT higher DT salinity of DT lake . DT salinity in turn affects which species of diatoms , types of algae , can thrive in DT lake . When PRP die , diatoms sink to DT bottom of DT lake and are buried in sediments on DT lakebed , creating a layered chronicle of DT salinity of DT lake — and by proxy DT speed of DT winds . Saunders ’ team extracted sediment cores from DT lakebed , focusing on layers WDT had accumulated during DT Holocene , DT present epoch in NNP ’s history WDT began about 11,700 NNS ago at DT end of DT last NN age . Having inferred DT speeds of westerlies over DT course of DT Holocene , PRP then looked at data from NN cores drilled in Antarctica to VB a direct measure of DT amount of CO₂ in DT atmosphere over DT same NN period . PRP found a clear correlation . “ If PRP look at periods when DT winds were above their average strengths , and periods when carbon dioxide was above its average concentration , PRP overlap , ” Saunders says . This has implications for our understanding of DT effect DT westerlies have on DT Southern Ocean ’s capacity to absorb carbon . Saunders ’ NN supports DT idea IN as DT westerlies speed up , DT Southern Ocean will outgas more CO₂ — as shown by Gray ’s report on wintertime data collected by DT SOCCOM floats — and goes against DT analysis of 35 NNS of ship - based data by Landschützer ’s team . Only more studies , along DT lines of Landschützer ’s attempt to reconcile DT various datasets , will help resolve this debate . EX ’s CD more factor WDT MD feed into DT vicious cycle WDT NNS fear MD already be underway in DT Southern Ocean . Changes in DT extensive Atlantic Ocean circulation system WDT includes DT Gulf Stream MD RB be exacerbating DT NN of DT Southern Ocean , which in turn MD be adding to DT poleward shift and intensification of DT westerlies . This circulation system , called DT Atlantic meridional overturning circulation , or AMOC , brings warm , salty surface NN to DT north , where PRP cools and sinks and then heads back to DT Southern Hemisphere through deeper ocean layers . NNS have found evidence IN DT AMOC has been slowing down , particularly in DT last 150 NNS compared to DT preceding 1,500 NNS . CD indication of this is IN particles being deposited on DT ocean floor have been getting smaller and smaller : Fast - flowing NN can whisk away smaller particles , allowing only DT larger particles to settle , whereas slower NN allows smaller and smaller particles to drop to DT floor . Some of DT AMOC ’s slowdown can be attributed to CD of DT consequences of JJ NN : an increasing supply of glacial meltwater into DT North Atlantic . This fresh NN reduces DT salinity , and hence DT density , of DT surface waters . DT formation of dense , salty , cold NN is essential for PRP to sink down to DT deep ocean in DT North , from where PRP makes its return to DT Southern Hemisphere . This process is being disrupted by NN NN . Since 2004 , a project called RAPID has deployed moorings across DT breadth and depth of DT Atlantic at latitude degrees 26N ( stretching from Florida to Morocco ) , to directly measure changes in DT velocity of DT AMOC . DT measurements show IN DT current is indeed slowing down . But because of inherent decade - to - decade variations in DT NN system , 15 NNS ’ worth of direct measurements is n’t enough to establish a trend . So Levke Caesar , then with DT Potsdam Institute for NNP Impact Research in Germany , and her colleagues extended this record back in NN by using actual measurements of NN surface temperatures from 1870 to 2016 , combined with a high - resolution NN model to reconstruct DT strength of DT AMOC over DT past 150 NNS or so . Their work shows IN DT circulation system ’s strength declined to a minimum around 1990 , then grew until DT early 2000s , and then started declining again . Other NNS have found similar results . As long as greenhouse gas NNS continue to rise , “ all NN models predict a slowdown of DT AMOC , ” Caesar says . Because DT AMOC transports heat from DT south to DT north , a slowdown effectively cools DT Northern Hemisphere and heats up DT Southern Hemisphere . This NN RB intensifies DT westerlies and shifts them toward DT South Pole , leading to a greater vertical churning of DT Southern Ocean , which MD contribute to JJ NN by weakening DT ocean ’s ability to absorb CO₂ . Since DT likely result is even more glacial meltwater flowing into DT North Atlantic , this MD further weaken DT AMOC . PRP has all DT makings of a system WDT ’s slipping out of control . A similar runaway process is thought to have ended DT last NN age , raising CO₂ levels from about 180 to 240 parts per million . This rise happened from about 17,500 NNS ago to 11,700 NNS ago , causing DT deglaciation WDT made NNP more habitable . Atmospheric CO ₂ levels are now past a whopping 410 ppm due to human activity , and rising . In a mere 250 NNS , PRP have increased CO ₂ levels by more than DT amount WDT melted an icy NN over thousands of NNS . DT winds are howling again over DT Southern Ocean and are dangerously close to awakening a beast WDT , until now , has been helping PRP by absorbing copious amounts of carbon . But even DT Southern Ocean is unlikely to cooperate forever . Editor 's note : An earlier version of DT map showing how DT westerlies are made had incorrect placement of NNP ’s geography . text: NNP Explained is a collaboration between DT Conversation , Stuff and DT NNP Zealand NNP NNP Centre to answer your questions about NN NN . If PRP have a question PRP ’d VB an expert to answer , please send PRP to climate.change@stuff.co.nz DT flight shaming movement has raised our awareness of air travel ’s contribution to NN NN . With all DT discussion , PRP might be surprised to learn IN air travel globally only accounts for about 3 % of DT NN human activities are causing . Why all DT fuss ? Before I explain , I should come clean . I am writing this on DT train from Christchurch to Kaikoura , where I will give a talk about my recent book # NoFly : walking DT talk on NN NN . I have some skin in this game . Read more : Flight shame : flying less plays a small but positive part in tackling NN NN Taking a train around NNP Zealand is no mean feat . In DT North Island , DT train between Auckland and Wellington runs only every second day . If PRP VBP off at a stop along DT way , PRP have to wait another two days to continue your journey . PRP can catch a bus , but PRP ’ll spend DT bus journey fantasising about DT possibility of an overnight train service . So why do PRP ? A good deal of JJ carbon NNS come from industrial processes or electricity generation under DT control of governments and corporations , rather than individual citizens . For JJ of PRP , a decision not to fly might be DT most significant reduction in NNS PRP can make as individuals . As Swedish NN activist Greta Thunberg has shown , refusing to fly RB sends a powerful signal to others , by showing IN PRP are willing to VB your own behaviour . Politicians and corporate sales departments will take note if PRP start acting together . Aviation affects DT NN in a variety of ways . Because any carbon dioxide PRP emit stays in DT atmosphere for hundreds of NNS , PRP does n’t matter much whether PRP release PRP from DT exhaust pipe of your car at NN level or from a jet engine several kilometres high . Per passenger , a flight from Auckland to Wellington will put a similar amount of carbon dioxide into DT air as driving solo in your car . Catching DT train will cut your carbon NNS seven - fold . When aircraft burn jet fuel , however , PRP RB emit short - lived gases IN nitrogen oxides , which can react with other gases in DT air within a day of being released . When nitrogen oxides are released at altitude PRP can react with oxygen to put more ozone into DT air , but can RB remove methane . Ozone and methane are both greenhouse gases , so this chain of chemical reactions can lead to both heating and cooling effects . Unfortunately DT net result when these processes are added together is to drive more NN . Depending on DT atmospheric conditions , aircraft can RB create contrails : clouds of tiny NN crystals . DT NN is not as clear cut on how contrails influence DT NN , but some studies suggest PRP MD have an effect as significant as DT carbon dioxide released during a flight . EX is RB considerable uncertainty as to whether aircraft exhaust might affect cloud formation itself - this MD be a further significant contribution to NN . Read more : NN explained : why do n't PRP have electric aircraft ? Offsetting , by planting trees or restoring natural wildlands , will take carbon dioxide back out of DT atmosphere . But PRP MD have to do this on a massive scale to feed our appetite for flight . NNS from international air travel are not included in DT Paris Agreement , although DT NNP Nations has been working on DT Carbon Offsetting and Reduction Scheme for International Aviation ( CORSIA ) , which MD begin to deal with these . Initially , DT scheme will be voluntary . Airlines flying routes between NNS WDT join DT scheme will have to offset any NNS above 2020 levels from January 2021 . NNS from flying stand to triple by 2050 if demand for air travel continues to grow . Even if air travel became carbon neutral through DT use of biofuels or electric planes , DT effects from contrails and interactions with clouds mean IN flying MD never be NN neutral . With no easy fixes on DT horizon , JJ NNS are thinking hard about their need to fly . This is why I took a NN off air travel ( alongside my colleague Quentin Atkinson ) in 2018 . I have been back on planes in 2019 , but I have learned how to reduce my flying , by combining trips and making better use of video conferencing . Fly if PRP must , offset if PRP can , but – if PRP are concerned about NN NN – CD of DT best things PRP MD choose to do is to fly less .

text: NN NN presents clear and pressing threats to business — materials and product shortages , price volatility , legal bans or consumer backlash , and damaged transportation infrastructure , to name just a few . But EX are opportunities as well . Lowitt , a consultant in DT sustainability field , has developed a series of detailed checklists WDT will help smart managers reduce operational , regulatory , and reputational risk while finding JJ ways to cut costs , improve performance , enhance customer relationships , and otherwise increase competitiveness . DT checklist recommendations , tested and refined through Lowitt ’s research into and work with firms including Coca - Cola , GE , and Owens Corning , cover four broad areas in DT product life cycle : sourcing , manufacturing , distribution , and consumption . Actions range from educating and incentivizing employees to use NN NN –conscious behavior to measuring and reporting key metrics to determining when alternative materials , methods , sites , or contract partners MD be called for . IN any such tool , DT checklists do n’t provide a CD - size - fits - all plan . text: AN ENORMOUS NN sheet is at risk of melting even if temperatures rise by just 2 °C , potentially sparking major NN chaos . NNS say IN if DT East Antarctic NNP Sheet – which is 60 times DT size of England – melts , NN levels MD rise by four metres , putting areas of DT UK at risk of disappearing entirely . Experts are now warning IN more needs to be done to prevent continued JJ NN . Melting NN can have a devastating effect on DT NN , causing DT NN to heat up more quickly , changing ocean circulation systems WDT regulate JJ weather , and increasing DT risk of flooding and tsunamis damage . A NN into historical NN loss suggests even " moderate NN " of NNP MD melt DT East Antarctic NNP Sheet . " With current JJ temperatures already CD degree higher than during pre-industrial times , future NN loss seems inevitable if PRP fail to reduce carbon NNS , " VBD Dr David Wilson , of Imperial College London , who worked on DT research . NNS have poured lots of effort into investigating DT West Antarctic NNP Sheet , which mostly sits on land below NN level . Due to its low - lying position , PRP contributes to most of DT continent 's NN melt today . But experts at Imperial College London and DT University of Queensland have now investigated risks facing DT East Antarctic NNP Sheet . DT EAIS is DT largest NN sheet on NNP , and poses a major hazard if PRP disappears . Now a NN in Nature suggests IN 2 °C of NN over " a couple of millennia " MD cause significant melting of DT EAIS . " Antarctica is around twice DT size of Australia , with NN sheets several kilometres thick and containing around half of DT NN 's fresh NN , " VBD Dr Kevin Welsh , at DT University of Queensland , a co-author on DT NN . " DT East Antarctic NNP Sheet covers about two thirds of DT area , and because its base is largely above NN level PRP was generally thought to be less sensitive to NN climates than DT adjacent West Antarctic NNP Sheet . " However , some areas – IN DT Wilkes Land Subglacial Basin , directly south of Australia – are below NN level and contain enough NN to raise JJ NN levels by several metres . " DT evidence PRP have suggests IN with DT predicted 2 °C NN in Antarctica – if sustained over a couple of millennia – DT sheet MD start melting in these locations . " Glaciers , which are created by NN sheets , grind up rocks on land . These rocks are then transported into DT nearby Southern Ocean as sediment . This creates a record of earlier erosion by DT NN sheet . Researchers chemically analysed layers of sediment from DT ocean floor , which MD have originated from DT Wilkes Subglacial Basin – collected as part of DT Integrated Ocean Drilling Program . DT NN looked at sediment layers WDT had settled on DT seafloor during DT four warm intervals occurring between NN ages over DT last 450,000 NNS . " Studying NN sheet behaviour in DT geological past can inform PRP about future changes , " VBD Dr Wilson . " By building a picture of how DT NN sheet has grown and shrunk as temperatures have fluctuated , PRP can understand DT response of DT EAIS to future NN . " DT team found chemical " fingerprints " in DT sediment which revealed DT patterns of erosion as DT NN sheet advanced and retreated . PRP turned out IN DT NN sheet had retreated from its current size during some of these warmer " interglacial " periods , between 125,000 and 400,000 NNS ago . Importantly , at DT NN , temperatures were as little as two degrees warmer than pre-industrial times – and CD degree warmer than today . During these warmer periods , JJ NN levels were between six and 13 metres higher than PRP are today . According to researchers , if all DT NN in DT Wilkes Subglacial Basin melted in modern times , JJ NN levels MD rise by up to four metres . " PRP found IN DT most extreme changes in DT NN sheet occurred during two interglacial periods 125,000 and 400,000 NNS ago , when JJ NN levels were several metres higher than PRP are today , " Dr Walsh explained . " These periods MD be analogues for future climates and PRP seems likely IN NN loss from DT East Antarctic NNP Sheet contributed to those higher NN levels . " NN loss contributes to rising JJ NN levels which are a threat to JJ coastal communities , and making projections requires a solid understanding of how sensitive these NN sheets are . " CD of DT biggest concerns about rising NN levels is DT risk than smaller , more common tsunamis MD have a more damaging effect than PRP do today . Last month , NNS issued a warning about DT risk of “ devastating tsunamis ” caused by NN NN . Research in NNP Advances suggested IN rising NN levels – caused by JJ NN – significantly increase DT threat of giant killer waves . Experts modelled DT impact of tsunamis based on NN level increases , and discovered worrying results . PRP found IN rising NN levels allowed tsunamis to reach much further inland , significantly increasing DT risk of floods . This means small tsunamis WDT might not be deadly today MD wreak havoc in DT future . “ Our research shows IN NN - level rise can significantly increase DT tsunami hazard , which means IN smaller tsunamis in DT future can have DT same adverse impacts as big tsunamis MD today , ” VBD Robert Weiss , a professor of geosciences at Virginia Tech . And if PRP VBP Britain is safe from tsunamis , VB again . Earlier this week , research revealed IN deadly tsunamis crashing into DT UK is more common than previously thought . NNS believe three killer waves have hit DT UK within DT last 10,000 NNS – raising DT possibility IN another NN MD be due . PRP already knew about CD of these : around 8,200 NNS ago , DT Storegga submarine landslide off DT coast of Norway sparked a 20 - metre high tsunami WDT swept across Shetland . text: DT aim of DT current paper is to update DT previous NN on NN NN fingerprints in European phenology and include as JJ plant species / phenophases as are available . Recent publications have exclusively focused on a few prominent spring leaf unfolding phases and results of those MD be strongly related to DT choice of analysed species , having different sensitivities and covering different seasons . Phenology is controlled by seasonal patterns in DT NN signal ( Lapenis et al. , 2014 ) and these will vary by location ( spatial differences in DT NN signal ) and NN period ( temporal differences in DT NN signal , e.g. Rutishauser et al. , 2009 ) . Consequently , this update is more than timely since DT NN signal has not been stable , but temporal variations or trends in NN NN have been reported , especially related to DT so called hiatus or standstill period ( Zang , Jochner ‐ Oette , Cortés , Rammig , & Menzel , 2019 ) . A publication has already indicated IN EX were no trends in spring and autumn phenology during this NN hiatus period ( Wang et al. , 2019 ) . Another phenological regime shift in DT mid‐1980s was RB related to discontinuous temperature changes ( Reid et al. , 2016 ) . Temperature sensitivity has RB been shown to vary with specific plant traits , such as evolutionary relatedness , and to support invasions and plant performance ( e.g. Wolkovich , Cook , & Davies , 2014 ) . For wheat and maize in agriculture EX are hints of geographic differences among cultivars in sensitivity to vernalization , day length and temperature ( Van Bussel , Stehfest , Siebert , Müller , & Ewert , 2015 ) . However , EX are still major knowledge gaps concerning DT so‐called ‘ false ’ phenological phases , such as sowing or harvesting in agriculture , whose timings are decided by farmers . DT GCB2006 NN and follow ‐up publications provided DT first evidence IN DT phenological signal in agriculture was weaker than DT signal for wild growing plant species ( Bock , Sparks , Estrella , & Menzel , 2013 ; Estrella , Sparks , & Menzel , 2007 ; Menzel , Sparks , Estrella , Koch , et al. , 2006 ; Menzel , Vopelius , Estrella , Schleip , & Dose , 2006 ) . However , PRP can be anticipated IN , sooner or later , agricultural management and / or choice of cultivars will RB be adapted to DT JJ potential growing seasons . DT drivers of autumn phenology , such as leaf colouring and leaf fall , are still far from being completely understood ( Estrella & Menzel , 2006 ; Gallinat , Primack , & Wagner , 2016 ; Gill et al. , 2015 ; Wu et al. , 2018 ) . Major factors WDT MD impact on DT results of this update are different changes in ( apparent ) temperature sensitivity ( e.g . Fu , Piao , et al. , 2015 ; Fu , Zhao , et al. , 2015 ) . Species ‐specific increases in heat requirements related to a decrease in chilling have been especially identified as DT main reason ( Fu , Piao , et al. , 2015 ) . However , EX are RB contrasting opinions for example , by Wang et al. ( 2017 ) . Güsewell , Furrer , Gehrig , and Pietragalla ( 2017 ) showed IN for Switzerland EX are still no indications of a lack of chilling leading to altered temperature sensitivities . Changes in temperature sensitivities are reported as not uniform over NN ( Chen et al. , 2019 ) and , in particular , a weakened temperature response was observed since 2000 ( Fu et al. , 2014 ) . Spatial variations in temperature sensitivity have been linked to mean annual temperature and to seasonal temperature range ( Lapenis , Henry , Vuille , & Mower , 2014 ; Menzel , Sparks , Estrella , & Roy , 2006 ; Wang et al. , 2014 ) . Both major backup systems to prevent a premature spring development ( chilling , photoperiod ) MD finally lead to nonlinear responses of phenological onset dates to forcing temperatures ( Jochner , Sparks , Laube , & Menzel , 2016 ) . Thus , DT well ‐accepted role of phenology as a NN NN indicator is based on DT formal attribution of shifted phenological onset dates to anthropogenic ‐induced NN ( Rosenzweig et al. , 2007 , 2008 ) , demonstrating at DT same NN IN DT phenological trends are not just natural variability , for example , as shown by Guan ( 2014 ) for two phenophases which unequivocally corresponded to DT respective winter / spring NN trends . Most studies , however , rely on proof of DT sensitivity of phenological phases to temperature as DT fundamental prerequisite of NN NN detection and attribution , and have linked phenological changes to temperature increases ( e.g . Cook et al. , 2012 ; Thackeray et al. , 2016 ) . Since EX is thorough evidence IN spring phenological development is RB partially triggered by fulfilment of winter chilling and by photoperiod ( e.g. Laube et al. , 2014 ; Tang et al. , 2016 ; Vitasse & Basler , 2013 ) , PRP is debated whether phenological changes still mirror DT recent ongoing NN , or mirror PRP to DT same extent as before . Therefore , an update of DT assessment of phenological changes across Europe and their attribution to NN NN is necessary . In contrast to DT GCB2006 publication , this update will uniquely concentrate on plant phenology . Although plant phenology is CD of DT oldest forms of environmental monitoring , with phenological observations taken by ancient civilizations ( Koch et al. , 2007 ; Schwartz , 2003 ) , PRP was only in DT 1990s IN its renaissance started with key publications on detection of NN NN impacts on JJ vegetation . Keeling , Chin , and Whorf ( 1996 ) were DT first to report a 7 day earlier start of DT growing season based on long‐term measurements of atmospheric CO 2 concentration , which Myneni , Keeling , Tucker , Asrar , and Nemani ( 1997 ) confirmed using normalized difference vegetation index satellite data from DT Northern Hemisphere . Menzel and Fabian ( 1999 ) then provided DT necessary ground truth by their analyses of long‐term European phenological data . JJ other papers , summarized in well ‐cited reviews and relevant chapters in IPCC reports ( e.g. Rosenzweig et al. , 2007 ; Walther et al. , 2002 ) , confirmed DT extraordinary role of phenology as a bio‐indicator of NN NN . While research initially focused purely on DT identification of changes , PRP then extended to communication of NN NN to DT general NN ( e.g. Van Vliet et al. , 2003 ) as well as on various ecological consequences of these changes ( Morisette et al. , 2009 ; Thackeray et al. , 2010 ) . Nevertheless , at DT beginning of this renewed research EX was a latent accusation of a publication bias , or cherry picking , in DT sense IN only DT most advancing records or extraordinary changes found their way into popular scientific journals . With more than 1,500 citations in DT Web of NNP Core Collection , this NN has a high relevance for DT scientific discourse on NN NN impacts on DT biosphere . In contrast , farmers ’ activities in autumn were still advancing , but to a lesser degree , although DT percentage of advancing trends slightly decreased . In contrast , DT FS was shortened by − 0.15 days / NN due to a smaller advancing trend in farmers ’ spring activities than in DT development of wild plant species , matching DT previous findings of Estrella et al. ( 2007 ) . PRP is important to notice IN spring development of winter cereals is ( at least ) comparable to DT of fruit trees and wild species . More specifically , based on percentages of significant trends matching DT NN , advancing farming activities are likely , ripening phases in summer are very likely and phenological spring phases , such as leaf unfolding and flowering , are very or extremely likely to mirror DT increasing temperatures . DT spatial approach confirmed this attribution , however , to a lesser degree . Seasonal NN was significantly associated with spring phases ’ advance in fruit trees and wild plant species , generative phases in crops as well as farmers ’ activities mirroring winter and spring NN ( descending order , F not with spring NN ) . Advancing farmers ’ summer activities clearly mirrored summer and autumn NN patterns . DT association in autumn was reversed with below average NN in winter and spring being linked to advanced leaf colouring and fall ( see equally Estrella & Menzel , 2006 ; Zohner & Renner , 2019 ) and less NN in summer being linked to advanced farmers ’ autumn activities . Most interestingly , what has been described as carry ‐over effects ( Sparks , Buras , Estrella , & Menzel , 2020 ; Zohner & Renner , 2019 ) , is depicted by this attribution analysis , where below average NN in summer was linked to advancing phenological trends in spring ( FWv , FWg , F ) . Our results clearly underline IN farmers ’ decisions ( weaker trends and smaller trend changes in spring and autumn ) MD be driven by other factors as well , although farmers seem to respond / adapt since their activities in spring were DT only phase to exhibit stronger advancing trends in Update . text: Mass extinctions are very important to how life evolved on NNP . For example , when an asteroid hit DT NNP 66 million NNS ago , DT resulting dinosaur extinction led mammals to take their place . My colleagues and I have published JJ research on DT mass extinction WDT took place 359 million NNS ago at DT boundary between DT Devonian and Carboniferous geological periods . EX have been JJ previous speculations as to DT cause of this event , including volcanic eruptions , asteroid impacts , NN NN , NN level changes , wildfires and DT rise of DT first forests . But PRP have shown IN DT extinctions on land at this NN MD have been caused by a catastrophic thinning of DT ozone layer WDT let in damaging levels of ultra-violet radiation . Something similar contributed to DT mass extinctions at DT end of DT Permian and Triassic periods , but these events were caused by volcanic eruptions . Our research suggests DT NNP has a natural internal process triggered by a VBG NN WDT can destroy DT ozone layer , a serious warning for our own period of NN NN . DT Late Devonian extinction played a significant role in DT development of vertebrate life . PRP included DT loss of DT dominant group of armoured freshwater fish . DT survivors were DT sharks and DT rather minor group of bony fish WDT subsequently spread out to dominate our younger oceans . DT event RB shaped our own evolution because PRP led to DT extinction of DT first four - legged “ tetrapods ” . These were “ fish ” whose fins had evolved to become limbs with between six and eight fingers and toes . DT first land - dwelling tetrapods with five fingers and toes – our ancestors – do n’t appear in DT fossil record until after this extinction . To find out exactly what caused DT Late Devonian extinction , PRP looked for evidence of what happened in DT atmosphere WDT was captured by fossilised plants from before and after DT event . In particular , PRP looked at DT resistant walls of DT microscopic remains of pollen and spores , taken from fossils found in East Greenland and released by dissolving DT rock samples in acid . DT resistant walls of spores and pollen are RB to protect DT cell contents from ultra-violet radiation . But EX is a brief interval between DT creation of a JJ cell and DT formation of its protective wall when PRP is vulnerable . DT kinds of spores PRP examined are covered in small spines WDT are normally identical in length and have perfectly pointed tips . But most of DT spines in our samples were malformed in a wild variety of shapes , suggesting DT DNA of their cells was damaged by ultra-violet radiation . This suggests IN DT NNP ’s protective ozone shield was down as DT spores were formed . Other spores and pollen had pigmented walls WDT acted as a protective tan , enabling those plants to survive . But a number of important plant groups quickly became extinct and DT forest ecosystem collapsed . Those groups WDT survived were still disrupted and PRP took several million NNS to rebuild , creating quite a different ecosystem in DT process . Our samples came from a very large ancient lake WDT existed all NN round despite being in a very arid part of DT NN . Such lakes only form when glaciers collapse and DT NN ’s seasonal monsoon is very active due to solar heat , so DT JJ NN must have been in a NN period . Other NNS have shown IN high summer temperatures over continental areas can increase DT transport of NN vapour high into DT atmosphere . This NN vapour carries with PRP organic carbon compounds WDT include chlorine , which are produced naturally by a wide variety of plants , algae and fungi . Once these compounds are near DT ozone layer , PRP release DT chlorine and this breaks down ozone molecules . This produces a positive feedback loop because a collapsing terrestrial ecosystem will release a flush of nutrients into DT oceans , which can cause a rapid increase in algae . So DT more DT ozone layer is damaged , DT more plants die , and DT more ozone - damaging compounds are released . Later on , DT ozone layer will naturally recover as DT NN cools and DT algae helps remove carbon dioxide from DT atmosphere . DT discovery of this potential JJ extinction mechanism indicates IN a NN NN , such as PRP have now , has DT potential to erode DT ozone layer to let in damaging ultra-violet radiation . This has consequences for all life on NNP , both on DT land and in shallow waters . PRP believe PRP is as important as recognising IN asteroid impacts caused mass extinctions . Once PRP knew about DT consequences of asteroid impacts , EX followed an intense collective research effort to assess DT threat . PRP now plot DT paths of all large extra-terrestrial objects likely to come close to DT NNP ’s orbit . Similarly , PRP now need to focus effort on understanding DT links between JJ NN and DT production and atmospheric transport of chlorine - bearing carbon compounds WDT have DT potential to cause similar destruction of our ozone layer . PRP now need to make further studies of DT rocks with malformed spores to work out DT duration of DT extinction and DT likely rate of temperature NN required to push enough ozone - destroying chemicals high into DT atmosphere . PRP RB VBP to do ultra-violet malformation experiments on living fern - IN plants which have spiny spores .

text: JJ surface temperature has been measured since 1880 at a network of ground - based and ocean - based sites . Over DT last century , DT average surface temperature of DT NNP has increased by about 1.0o F . DT eleven warmest NNS this century have all occurred since 1980 , with 1995 DT warmest on record . DT higher latitudes have warmed more than DT equatorial regions . Beginning in 1979 , satellites have been used to measure DT temperature of DT atmosphere up to a height of 30,000 feet . DT long - term surface record and DT recent satellite observations differ , but DT fact is not surprising : DT two techniques measure DT temperature of different parts of DT NNP system ( DT surface , and various layers of DT atmosphere ) . In addition to this , a variety of factors , such as DT presence of airborne materials from DT 1991 eruption of DT volcano Mt. Pinatubo , affect each record in a different way . Satellite observations were initially interpreted as showing a slight cooling , but more recent analyses accounting for natural , short - term fluctuations imply NN , just as DT ground - based measurements have indicated over a longer NN period . As more data from DT satellite record become available , and as DT quality of measurements is improved , comparison of these two records should yield additional insights . What does NN do ? A warmer NNP speeds up DT JJ NN cycle : DT exchange of NN among DT oceans , atmosphere , and land . Higher temperatures cause more evaporation , and soils will tend to dry out faster . Increased amounts of NN in DT atmosphere will mean more rain or snow overall . PRP MD be seeing DT first signs of changes in DT NN cycle . Since DT beginning of DT century , precipitation in DT NNP NNPS has increased by about 6 percent , while DT frequency of intense precipitation events ( heavy downpours of more than two inches per day ) has increased by 20 percent . Such events can cause flooding , soil erosion , and even loss of life . In some midcontinental areas , increased evaporation has led to drought because DT heavy rains fell elsewhere . EX is RB evidence IN ecosystems are reacting to NN . Between 1981 and 1991 , DT length of DT growing season in DT northern high latitudes ( between 45 oand 70o N ) increased by a total of up to twelve days , as documented by satellite imagery . Greening in spring and summer occurred up to eight days earlier , and vegetation continued to photosynthesize an estimated four days longer . JJ mean NN level has risen 4 to 10 inches over DT last 100 NNS , mainly because NN expands when heated . DT melting of glaciers , which has occurred worldwide over DT last century , RB contributes to DT rise . Formerly frozen soils ( permafrost ) in DT Alaskan and Siberian arctic have RB begun to melt , damaging both ecosystems and infrastructure . Melting and tundra NN will RB lead to decay of organic matter and DT release of trapped carbon and methane , creating an additional source of greenhouse gases .

An ‘ informal ’ explanation of a Lunar Standstill event PRP can read from DT Wikipedia archives , and which says : " At DT major lunar standstill , which takes place every 18.6 NNS , DT range of DT declination of DT Moon reaches a maximum . As a result , at high latitudes , DT Moon appears to move in just two weeks from high in DT sky to low on DT horizon . This NN appears to have had special significance for DT Bronze Age societies who built DT megalithic monuments in Britain , and PRP RB has significance for some neo -pagan religions . DT next major lunar standstill occurs in 2006 . As DT NNP spins on its axis , DT stars above PRP appear to move in circles . PRP appears to PRP as if all DT stars are fixed in a great sphere surrounding PRP . In DT same way IN PRP measure positions on DT NN using latitude and longitude , PRP measure positions of stars on this sphere in Right Ascension ( equivalent to longitude ) and Declination ( equivalent to latitude ) . If PRP stand at a place on DT NN which has latitude 50° , then DT stars directly above PRP have a declination of 50° . Unlike DT stars , DT Sun and Moon do not have a fixed declination . As DT NNP travels its annual orbit around DT Sun , with its rotational axis tilted at about 23.5° from DT axis of orbital motion ( a straight line joining a point on DT tropic of cancer DT ' opposite ' point on DT tropic of capricorn ) , DT Sun 's declination changes from +23.5° in June to - 23.5° in December . Thus , in DT Northern hemisphere , DT Sun is higher in DT sky in June , causing summer , than PRP is in December , when DT Sun is low in DT sky and is only above DT horizon for a short NN , causing winter . DT Moon RB changes in declination , but PRP does so in only a month , instead of a NN for DT Sun . So PRP might VB from a declination of +25° to - 25° in just two weeks , returning to + 25 ° two weeks later . Thus , in just CD month DT moon can move from being high in DT sky , to low on DT horizon , and back again . But , unlike DT Sun , DT maximum and minimum declination reached by DT Moon RB varies . This is because DT orbit of DT Moon 's revolution about DT NNP is inclined by about 5° to DT orbit of DT NNP 's revolution around DT Sun , and so DT maximum declination of DT Moon varies from ( 23.5° - 5° ) =18.5° to ( 23.5°+5° ) =28.5° . DT effect of this is IN at CD particular NN ( DT minor lunar standstill ) , DT Moon will VB its declination during DT month from +18.5° to - 18.5° , which is a total movement of 37° . This is not a particularly big NN , and MD not be very noticeable in DT sky . However , 9.3 NNS later , during DT major lunar standstill , DT Moon will VB its declination during DT month from +28.5° to - 28.5° , which is a total movement of 57° , and which is enough to take PRP from high in DT sky to low on DT horizon in just two weeks . text: A hydrocarbon is an organic chemical compound composed exclusively of hydrogen and carbon atoms . Hydrocarbons are naturally - occurring compounds and form DT basis of crude oil , natural gas , coal , and other important NN sources . Hydrocarbons are highly combustible and produce carbon dioxide , NN , and heat when PRP are burned . Therefore , hydrocarbons are highly effective as a source of fuel . Hydrocarbons occur naturally throughout DT NN , originating from plant and animal fossils WDT have been formed by DT forces of temperature and weight over millennia . PRP are mostly found deep underground , in porous rock formations ( such as sandstone , limestone , and shale ) . Porous rock formations are often found in large bodies of NN , so EX is an immense quantity of hydrocarbons trapped deep beneath DT oceans . Oil and natural gas exploration companies use advanced engineering techniques to identify these potential reservoirs and pull their resources to DT surface for human use . Examples of such technologies include offshore oil platforms , directional drilling , and enhanced oil recovery ( EOR ) techniques . Hydrocarbons are very important for DT modern economy . Globally , hydrocarbons are responsible for roughly 85 % of NN consumption . This figure MD actually understate DT role of hydrocarbons in DT economy by a significant margin because PRP are used in a wide range of applications aside from their use as a source of NN . For example , refined petroleum has been used to produce myriad derivative materials WDT play critical roles in DT JJ economy , such as plastics , solvents , and lubricants . Different techniques are used to extract hydrocarbons , depending on DT type and location of DT reserve . For example , hydraulic fracturing — better known as “ fracking ” — is used to extract natural gas from shale rock by using pressurized fracking fluid to create fissures through which DT gas can escape to DT surface . Mining is used to access oil sands , which are unconventional deposits of crude oil WDT are heavily intermixed with sand and sandstone . Unfortunately , PRP is now understood IN EX is a serious environmental cost to using hydrocarbons as a primary source of NN . Greenhouse gasses released during DT combustion of hydrocarbons are contributing to NN NN . DT process of oil and gas extraction can damage DT surface environment and surrounding groundwater of DT extraction site . JJ economists argue IN hydrocarbon NN production involves substantial negative externalities WDT are not sufficiently represented in DT market price of oil and gas . In fact , considering DT mounting cost of NN - NN - related phenomena , JJ argue IN these externalities significantly outweigh any cost savings associated with hydrocarbons . To address these concerns , EX is a growing movement toward DT use of renewable NN sources , such as solar , nuclear , wind , and geothermal power . Alongside innovations in battery technology and “ smart grid ” infrastructure , these JJ NN alternatives MD play a significantly larger role in JJ NN production in DT NNS and decades ahead .

text: A noticeable increase in mean temperature has already been observed in Switzerland and summer temperatures up to 4.8 K warmer are expected by 2090 . This article reviews DT observed impacts of NN NN on biodiversity and considers some perspectives for DT future at DT national level . DT following impacts are already evident for all considered taxonomic groups : elevation shifts of distribution towards mountain summits , spread of thermophilous species , colonisation by JJ species from warmer areas and phenological shifts . Additionally , in DT driest areas , increasing droughts are affecting tree survival and fish species are suffering from warm temperatures in lowland regions . These observations are coherent with model projections , and future changes will probably follow DT current trends . These changes will likely cause extinctions for alpine species ( competition , loss of habitat ) and lowland species ( temperature or drought stress ) . In DT very urbanised Swiss landscape , DT high fragmentation of DT natural ecosystems will hinder DT dispersal of JJ species towards mountains . Moreover , disruptions in species interactions caused by individual migration rates or phenological shifts are likely to have consequences for biodiversity . Conversely , DT inertia of DT ecosystems ( species longevity , restricted dispersal ) and DT local persistence of populations will probably result in lower extinction rates than expected with some models , at least in 21st century . PRP is thus very difficult to estimate DT impact of NN NN in terms of species extinctions . A greater recognition by society of DT intrinsic value of biodiversity and of its importance for our existence will be essential to put in place effective mitigation measures and to safeguard a maximum number of native species .

text: — Our thanks to Kara Rogers and DT Britannica Blog , where this post first appeared on Oct. 12 , 2011 . Chirping from DT talus slopes of DT Teton Range in DT Rocky Mountains , DT American pika ( ) sends a warning call to intruders — in this case humans climbing up DT switchbacks in Grand Teton National Park ’s Cascade Canyon . Sounding its alarm from a rocky perch , then darting into crevices and shadow on DT steep slope , DT rodent - sized , round - eared , brownish gray pika goes largely unnoticed . But as DT second species petitioned for protection under DT U.S. Endangered Species Act ( ESA ) because of NN NN - associated threats ( DT polar bear was DT first ) , DT pika cannot afford to be overlooked for much longer . DT American pika lives primarily at elevations between 8,000 and 13,000 feet , though PRP MD be found at significantly lower elevations , including a little above NN level . Low - elevation pika populations , however , are at high risk of NN NN , particularly local NN and decreased precipitation . Populations of pika in Yosemite National Park , for example , have migrated more than 500 feet upslope over DT course of DT last century , a shift coincident with a temperature increase of 5.4 °F in Yosemite during DT same period of NN . More significantly , over DT course of only a decade — between 1999 and 2008 — pikas in DT Great Basin on DT eastern edge of DT Sierra Nevada experienced a nearly five - fold increase in extinction rate and an 11 - fold increase in DT rate of upslope retreat . Pikas EX are now moving upslope at a rate of 475 feet per decade . In 2010 , despite DT documented loss of pikas and evidence linking pika declines and range shifts with NN NN , DT U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service ( FWS ) decided not to protect DT American pika under DT ESA . DT decision was denounced by DT nonprofit Centers for Biological Diversity , which had petitioned for DT species ’ protection , and was supported by some biologists , who claimed IN most populations of DT American pika are stable . Pikas , however , are highly susceptible to warm temperatures and will die within several hours of constant exposure to temperatures of 75 to 78 °F . Their survival RB appears to depend heavily on contiguous habitat . For instance , a NN of historical pika population sites in DT southern Rockies , where pika habitat extends over a large area , revealed IN just four out of 69 populations had been extirpated since DT 1980s . DT extirpations occurred at sites WDT were once wet but WDT had dried out over DT course of DT last 100 NNS . Contiguous habitat and upslope migration are DT pika ’s only hope for escape from local NN NN and drying . But at higher elevations , food MD be scarce and DT NN too cold , and given DT isolation of pika populations , PRP remains to be seen whether migration and dispersal to JJ areas can actually rescue DT species . Furthermore , several decades into DT future , DT high , mountainous elevations where pikas can now find refuge MD no longer be cool and wet enough to support their survival . Indeed , NN prediction models have suggested IN summertime temperatures in pika habitat will increase by 5.4 °F by 2050 . While DT FWS cited this figure in its report explaining why pika do not warrant protection under DT ESA , such an increase will render DT lower elevations of JJ mountain ranges , including DT Teton Range , uninhabitable for pika . And while PRP is difficult to predict precise temperature increases beyond 2050 , temperatures likely will continue to rise , forcing DT American pika higher and higher , further restricting its range and its chances of survival in DT process .

text: ( Reuters ) - Unilever Plc ( ULVR.L ) VBD on Monday PRP will invest 1 billion euros in a fund to invest in NN NN projects and reduce to net zero greenhouse gas NNS from all its products by 2039 , 11 NNS ahead of DT Paris Agreement deadline . DT fund will invest in projects including reforestation , NN preservation and carbon sequestration over DT next ten NNS , PRP VBD . DT net zero emission target is an extension of efforts already underway to cut NNS within DT company by 2030 - such as reducing electricity consumption within offices . Unilever ’s total greenhouse gas footprint was around 60 million tonnes of carbon dioxide equivalent in 2019 according to its website . “ PRP are now VBG much wider in our commitments , PRP call PRP a cradle to shelf commitment ... across DT value chain , ” Unilever Chief Supply Chain Officer , Marc Engel VBD . All packaging will show DT carbon footprint of DT product in DT future , DT company VBD . Unilever joins a handful of companies in promising net zero NNS from their supply chain . Kit -Kat maker Nestle ( NESN.S ) and German elevator maker Thyssenkrupp AG ( TKAG.DE ) are others though their targets are set for 2050 , which is DT deadline set by DT Paris Agreement on NN NN to limit JJ NN to 1.5° degrees . text: Lauren E. Oakes is a Conservation Scientist with DT Wildlife Conservation Society , an Adjunct Professor at Stanford University in DT Department of NNP System NNP , and DT author of " In Search of DT Canary Tree . text: DT evidence for anthropogenic NN NN is now clear and convincing . DT NNP ’s surface has warmed by more than 0.8 °C over DT past century , and by approximately 0.6 °C in DT past three decades . 1 This NN has been linked to more extreme weather conditions such as intense floods and droughts , heavier and more frequent storms , and a possible increase in frequency and intensity of DT El Niño Southern Oscillation . These changes are largely caused by human activities , mainly DT burning of fossil fuels releasing carbon dioxide ( CO2 ) WDT traps heat within DT atmosphere . These CO2 NNS continue to rise , and NN models project DT average surface temperature will rise by 1.1 °C to 6.4 °C over DT 21st century . 2 Since 1990 , WHO has published a series of reports on NN NN and has participated in review processes such as DT Intergovernmental Panel on NNP NNP . These activities have outlined four key characteristics of DT NN risks generated by a NN and a more variable NN . First , these hazards are diverse , JJ and probably irreversible over human NN scales . PRP range from increased risks of extreme weather , such as fatal heat waves , floods and storms , to less dramatic but potentially more serious effects on infectious NN dynamics , shifts to long - term drought conditions in JJ regions , melting of glaciers WDT supply freshwater to large population centres , and NN level increases leading to salination of sources of agriculture and drinking NN . Second , DT NN impacts of NN NN are potentially huge . JJ of DT most important JJ killers are highly sensitive to climatic conditions . Malaria , diarrhoea and protein - NN malnutrition together cause more than 3 million deaths each NN . 3 Third , these risks are inequitable , in IN DT greenhouse gases WDT cause NN NN originate mainly from developed NNS , but DT NN risks are concentrated in DT poorest nations , which have contributed least to DT problem . 4 Finally , JJ of DT projected impacts on NN are avoidable , through a combination of JJ NN interventions in DT short term , support for adaptation measures in NN - related sectors such as agriculture and NN management , and a long - term strategy to reduce human impacts on NN . Threats to NN are often cited to justify actions to mitigate or adapt to NN NN ; for example , NNP Nations Secretary - General Kofi Annan ’s 2006 speech in Nairobi.5 For all DT attention WDT these issues receive , however , a comprehensive strategy to support a JJ NN response is conspicuously lacking . This strategy is urgently needed , both because DT NN community has a duty to counter emerging threats , and because increased attention to NN NN offers opportunities to focus on DT most disadvantaged populations ’ current needs . For example , DT international community has agreed on DT principle of a JJ NN NN adaptation fund , funded by a 2 % levy on a multibillion - dollar Clean Development Mechanism .6 However , this opportunity to strengthen JJ NN can be seized only if DT NN sector knows what PRP should do differently because of NN NN . DT development of a comprehensive strategy will take NN , but some essential principles are already clear . A JJ problem requires a strategy of international dimensions WDT can translate into regional and local actions . Just as NN NN ’s underlying causes are JJ , its NN implications do not respect national boundaries . Impacts in CD location , such as infectious NN epidemics or population displacements caused by droughts or rising NN levels , quickly spread across national borders . Coordinated investments in preventive measures therefore contribute to DT “ JJ JJ good ” of reducing DT risk of NN emergencies . DT challenge is simplified somewhat by DT fact IN NN NN is expected to lead mainly to changes in existing NN issues rather than to DT emergence of JJ and unfamiliar diseases . An important guiding principle therefore is to increase DT priority given to currently important NN burdens WDT are likely to be worsened by NN NN . Such a “ no regrets ” strategy will bring important JJ NN benefits under any plausible future NN conditions . Adaptation to NN NN is essentially a matter of basic JJ NN protection . DT challenges of rapid environmental , demographic and social changes all call for greater emphasis on NN prevention , providing a better balance with DT current focus on curative and reactive measures . DT necessary preventive actions to deal with most NN - sensitive diseases are already quite clear . NN NN and other environmental stresses should help to refocus political and financial commitments to implement these measures . CD emerging environmental NN threat is DT decline in JJ freshwater resources , caused mainly by increasing rates of NN extraction and contamination . NN NN is expected to worsen this decline in NN quality and quantity , particularly in already dry regions such as DT eastern Mediterranean and north Africa . Scaling up NN and sanitation services and providing point - of - use disinfection MD reduce DT current burden of NN and ameliorate DT NN impacts of decreasing NN supplies . Such interventions already have a very high cost–benefit ratio; 7 DT threat of NN NN makes these preventive NN measures an even wiser investment . As NN stresses intensify , governments MD protect NN by strengthening and enforcing their regulatory frameworks to ensure DT safe use of JJ NN sources WDT will become increasingly important : wastewater , excreta and greywater in agriculture and aquaculture . 8 Effective surveillance and response systems are essential in managing any infectious NN , but PRP become even more important under conditions of rapid NN . These conditions include climatic shifts as well as increasing rates of movement of and contact between humans , pathogens and reservoirs . These conditions all require improved human NN surveillance integrated with monitoring of NN and other environmental conditions WDT favour NN outbreaks , including NN in wildlife and agricultural animals . NN NN RB strengthens DT case for reinforcing response systems for infectious NN outbreaks , including predefined action plans and maintenance of DT control resources and personnel capacity necessary to mount effective responses . DT impacts of current and future natural disasters MD be reduced by DT NN sector defining integrated measures WDT address DT root causes of vulnerability , and planning for effective responses after such events . For example , DT NN impacts of floods can be reduced by land management policies WDT reduce deforestation and conserve DT integrity of watersheds and coastal zones , minimize DT physical impacts of mudslides and storm surges , and decrease DT chances of sewage contamination . Post - flooding NN effects can be reduced by adequately planned and funded NN - sector responses , including interventions to control outbreaks of vector - borne and NN - related diseases . Since 2000 , WHO has worked with DT NNP Meteorological Organization and DT UN Environment Programme to raise awareness of NN NN ’s implications for DT NN sectors of highly vulnerable regions . DT necessary next step is to inform and support national NN actors in taking concrete actions to protect NN . For example , WHO is addressing this need by initiating a JJ project in 2006 on piloting approaches to protect NN in changing climates .9 In partnership with DT UN Development Programme and with funding from DT NNP Environmental Facility , this initiative is being implemented in seven vulnerable NNS . In each , DT national NN ministry chairs an intersectoral team WDT has identified priority NN risks from NN NN given local environmental socioeconomic and NN contexts . Through DT course of DT initiative , this team will RB identify , implement , monitor and refine interventions to minimize NN risks . DT project will thereby support targeted interventions in these NNS , strengthen institutional capacity to address NN risks , involve an increasingly informed and engaged NN sector in adapting to NN NN , and extract lessons WDT are applicable to other NNS . PRP will RB develop monitoring mechanisms to ensure IN resources are applied effectively in adaptation projects within DT NN sector , and inform evaluations of support through this mechanism as compared with more general NN or development aid . This initiative is important preparation for DT wider action WDT will be necessary to meet DT worldwide challenge of adapting to NN risks from NN NN . DT actions described above represent “ safe investments ” for NN NN adaptation funds within DT NN sector . However , JJ climatic risks to NN lie at least partly outside DT NN sector ’s normal sphere of action . Perhaps most critically , NN NN has DT capacity to suppress agricultural yields , with DT greatest risks in Africa,10 where malnutrition is already DT largest single contributor to NN burdens . 11 Some of DT most effective actions by NN professionals MD therefore involve supporting other sectors ’ efforts to mitigate and adapt to NN NN . Much work still needs to be done in this area , including : Ultimately , however , DT JJ NN community needs to VB beyond reacting to a changing NN . A true preventive strategy needs to ensure DT maintenance and development of healthy environments from local to JJ levels . In DT long term , sustainable development and protection of ecosystem services are fundamentally necessary for human NN .13 This is not just a case of protecting future generations , as even in DT short term development choices WDT protect DT NN can benefit JJ NN significantly . DT intersection of NN , transport , NN and NN provides an example of this . DT Stern Review of DT economics of NN NN argues IN DT long - term benefits of major investments to cut greenhouse gas NNS MD vastly outweigh their costs , and IN these are needed to avoid potentially catastrophic impacts on DT JJ economy . 12 This coincides with a WHO assessment IN feasible improvements in environmental conditions MD reduce DT JJ NN burden by more than 25%.14 Much of DT current burden is due to unhealthy NN and transport services . Changing these systems to reduce NN NN MD therefore RB bring significant and largely unacknowledged JJ NN gains . Improving access to JJ and active transport MD greatly reduce CO2 NNS , while RB cutting DT 800 000 annual JJ deaths from outdoor air pollution , DT 1.2 million annual deaths from traffic accidents , and DT 1.9 million deaths from physical inactivity . 11 Changing DT poorest communities ’ domestic NN technologies MD reduce DT 1.5 million annual indoor air pollution deaths . 15 DT critical next stage for DT NN community is a more direct and assertive engagement with DT environment and JJ sectors to ensure IN NN - supporting technological and development choices are implemented . Human - induced NN NN is an emerging threat WDT rightly commands widespread policy and JJ attention . Along with other rapid changes associated with JJ population and JJ growth , NN NN strains existing weak points in NN protection systems and calls for reconsideration of JJ NN priorities . DT most effective responses are likely to be strengthening of DT key functions of environmental management , surveillance and response to safeguard NN from natural disasters and changes in infectious NN patterns , and a more pro-active approach to ensure IN development decisions serve DT ultimate goal of improving human NN .16 For DT most part these are not JJ interventions but existing tools underutilized due to DT “ true killers ” : lack of political commitment and of financial resources . 17 NN NN therefore demands IN PRP intensify our efforts in preventive JJ NN and place DT crucial task at DT core of sustainable development . ■ • Surface temperature analysis : analysis graphs and plots . NN chief says NN leaders must recognize EX is no option except to speed - up and scale - up action to tackle JJ NN , warning IN continuing on DT current path will lead to “ a catastrophe . ” Patricia Espinosa stressed in two recent interviews with DT Associated Press IN NN NNS are saying EX ’s still a chance to make things right “ but DT window of opportunity is closing very soon ” and DT NN has 12 NNS until carbon NNS reach “ a point of no return . ” DT means DT NN needs to accelerate all efforts to keep from reaching DT level , “ and therefore all efforts are absolutely indispensable ” to cut carbon NNS and keep temperatures from rising , she VBD .
